Currently these variables are defined in the fib plugin for announcing routes. If define them again in topo file, there are two sources of these information. However, I feel that topo file is a better place for these definitions. The fib plugin can try to get values from topo file. If no value is in topo file, then the fib plugin can fallback to use default value. So, more changes are needed to make it complete.
* Update the [fib plugin](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/common/plugins/fib.py)
* Add the definitions to other topo files as well.

Can you make those changes as well?

> Currently these variables are defined in the fib plugin for announcing routes. If define them again in topo file, there are two sources of these information. However, I feel that topo file is a better place for these definitions. The fib plugin can try to get values from topo file. If no value is in topo file, then the fib plugin can fallback to use default value. So, more changes are needed to make it complete.
> 
> * Update the [fib plugin](https://github.com/Azure/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/common/plugins/fib.py)
> * Add the definitions to other topo files as well.
> 
> Can you make those changes as well?

@wangxin make changes in latest commit.

announced 82877 routes on t1, arp TC passed

Should we use the admin up and assume that for SFPs which are not connected the user should do admin down?

From: Joe LeVeque <notifications@github.com>
Sent: Thursday, November 19, 2020 12:13 AM
To: Azure/sonic-mgmt <sonic-mgmt@noreply.github.com>
Cc: Liat Grozovik <liatg@nvidia.com>; Comment <comment@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [Azure/sonic-mgmt] [Platform_api test] Rule out non-present Transceivers from SFP Platform API tests (#2550)


@jleveque requested changes on this pull request.

I think we need a way to tell the test whether to expect all transceivers are present or to ignore absent transceivers. If not, there could be an issue where a transceiver is present but the API call is broken and returns non-present and the test would not catch this case.

—
You are receiving this because you commented.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://nam11.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2FAzure%2Fsonic-mgmt%2Fpull%2F2550%23pullrequestreview-533924260&data=04%7C01%7Cliatg%40nvidia.com%7C8a83e6faadd64a7391c208d88c0f2902%7C43083d15727340c1b7db39efd9ccc17a%7C0%7C0%7C637413344025469125%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=xz9ReD1vpTECLgD6tudCeHEf8aEdK4VATr53Malue%2Fw%3D&reserved=0>, or unsubscribe<https://nam11.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fnotifications%2Funsubscribe-auth%2FAKTABA74CP7G4JQYP6PV2SLSQRBHTANCNFSM4TZXLWZA&data=04%7C01%7Cliatg%40nvidia.com%7C8a83e6faadd64a7391c208d88c0f2902%7C43083d15727340c1b7db39efd9ccc17a%7C0%7C0%7C637413344025469125%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C1000&sdata=D4ayd5nC%2F7FsG4quWY6Qc9j%2B9ZVHua2u189wVUecG4g%3D&reserved=0>.

I feel like the test itself should be told whether to expect all transceivers present or to ignore transceivers which are reporting as absent. I don't know of a good method to pass this information to Pytest. Maybe we could check for an environment variable? By default, the test would expect all transceivers present, but if the environment variable is set it will ignore all absent transceivers?

@liat-grozovik @jleveque although we are able to get the interface "admin up" status from sonic-mgmt, but still it's missing the knowledge about the mapping between the interface and the SFP object index fetched from platform API, it would be too complicated to add this to sonic-mgmt.  I would suggest adding an option to these test cases, by default it will assume all SFP exist, with this option it will only check the present SFPs.
@jleveque and @wangxin any further comments?
LGTM. @wangxin to review, also.
LGTM

reviews.body: I think we need a way to tell the test whether to expect all transceivers are present or to ignore absent transceivers. If not, there could be an issue where a transceiver is present but the API call is broken and returns non-present and the test would not catch this case.

reviews.body:
Thank you for the test case
I think the logic should be following:
1. Generate random ip address
2. Check that the ip address is routed through default routes, if not - go to item 1
3. Extract physical interfaces which are used as interfaces in default routes
4. Start capturing on the interfaces.

Can you please check that your test will FAIL when you remove
```ip nht resolve-via-default```
from the FRR config?

We already had a check for ```critical_process``` in ```sanity_check```.  Is it necessary to add another check?

> We already had a check for `critical_process` in `sanity_check`. Is it necessary to add another check?

I think these two sanity checks are independent of each other. Specifically the function `check_processes(...)` in sanity check will check whether all the critical processes are running or not before running the a pytest script. However, the function `check_monit(...)` will check whether Monit is running or not and whether the status of services monitored by Monit is in correct status or not.

@wangxin @yxieca - I changed the code in __init__.py to use pytest_assert. But, are failing vsimage tests. We are getting 
```
PluginValidationError: unknown hook 'pytest_assert' in plugin <module 'tests.common.plugins.sanity_check' from '/data/sonic-mgmt/tests/common/plugins/sanity_check/__init__.pyc'>
```
We are not sure how to resolve this - would you be able to please help out.

> @wangxin @yxieca - I changed the code in **init**.py to use pytest_assert. But, are failing vsimage tests. We are getting
> 
> ```
> PluginValidationError: unknown hook 'pytest_assert' in plugin <module 'tests.common.plugins.sanity_check' from '/data/sonic-mgmt/tests/common/plugins/sanity_check/__init__.pyc'>
> ```
> 
> We are not sure how to resolve this - would you be able to please help out.

Because it is in a pytest plugin, pytest is trying to interpret `pytest_assert` as a hook function. You can try this:
```
from tests.common.helpers.assertions import pytest_assert as pt_assert
```
@wangxin  Thanks for the suggestion. That worked.
@yxieca  - can you please review and approve this PR.
retest vsimage please

@irene-pan1202 can you fill the PR template with the request information? Particularly, explain why you made this change?

Thanks @irene-pan1202 , can you please reference this excerpt from [rfc:2131](https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-dhc-implementation-02#section-4.7.2)
```
     4.7.2 Relay Agent Port Usage
     
        Relay agents should use port 67 as the source port number.  Relay
        agents always listen on port 67, but port 68 has sometimes been used
        as the source port number probably because it was copied from the
        source port of the incoming packet.
     
        Cable modem vendors would like to install filters blocking outgoing
        packets with source port 67.
     
        RECOMMENDATIONS:
     
        O  Relay agents MUST use 67 as their source port number.
     
        O  Relay agents MUST NOT forward packets with non-zero giaddr
           unless the source port number on the packet is 67.
```

if I recall correctly, the behavior here matched the captured packets from relay agent. I am reluctant to whether stick with the standard or stick with the dhcrelay behavior.

@tahmed-dev  May I ask what scenario of this test case be ? Relay agent <--> device <--> DHCP server, or DHCP client <--> device <--> DHCP server
from the packet content, it looks like to test Relay agent <--> DHCP server,  but the UDP port it used is for client <--> server scenario?

> @tahmed-dev May I ask what scenario of this test case be ? Relay agent <--> device <--> DHCP server, or DHCP client <--> device <--> DHCP server
> from the packet content, it looks like to test Relay agent <--> DHCP server, but the UDP port it used is for client <--> server scenario?

Thanks @irene-pan1202 it is the first scenario and so, I agree it should be port 67 (server port) only.

reviews.body: The overall approach looks OK to me, but I would recommend going through and using `wait_until` from `common/utilities` in places where waiting is necessary (I think I pointed out most of them). It might also be worth considering using this in some places where there is a static 30-60s wait time to improve test stability.
LGTM, though I think Ying's feedback would be good to incorporate

Is the k8s cluster pre-configured offline?

> Is the k8s cluster pre-configured offline?

Yes, the k8s master cluster is pre-configured using `testbed-cli.sh` script before the test is run. The `check_k8s_vms` fixture makes sure that the k8s master cluster is online before running the test
retest vsimage please

> > Is the k8s cluster pre-configured offline?
> 
> Yes, the k8s master cluster is pre-configured using `testbed-cli.sh` script before the test is run. The `check_k8s_vms` fixture makes sure that the k8s master cluster is online before running the test

Thanks. I was thinking how to skip these cases on current topo without k8s. I have two ideas
1. Add some patch in run_test.sh. If the master node is not assigned, the script is skipped
2. Add a check at the beginning of test script. For example, we may check the kubelet service. Skip the case if kubelet service is absent.

> > > Is the k8s cluster pre-configured offline?
> > 
> > 
> > Yes, the k8s master cluster is pre-configured using `testbed-cli.sh` script before the test is run. The `check_k8s_vms` fixture makes sure that the k8s master cluster is online before running the test
> 
> Thanks. I was thinking how to skip these cases on current topo without k8s. I have two ideas
> 
> 1. Add some patch in run_test.sh. If the master node is not assigned, the script is skipped
> 2. Add a check at the beginning of test script. For example, we may check the kubelet service. Skip the case if kubelet service is absent.

Thanks for pointing this out, Bing. I have not tried running pytests with  `run_tests.sh` `-t` option before, I have only used an individual DUT. I tried adding a patch to `run_tests.sh` by adding `k8s` to `SKIP_FOLDERS` string and removing `k8s` from `SKIP_FOLDERS` when master node is assigned. Would that work? 

Kubelet service is up when the DUT is connected to a master. It is possible that the kubelet service may be down even when a master has been assigned- unless we enforce that the DUT must start as joined to the master before running k8s pytests.

> > > > Is the k8s cluster pre-configured offline?
> > > 
> > > 
> > > Yes, the k8s master cluster is pre-configured using `testbed-cli.sh` script before the test is run. The `check_k8s_vms` fixture makes sure that the k8s master cluster is online before running the test
> > 
> > 
> > Thanks. I was thinking how to skip these cases on current topo without k8s. I have two ideas
> > 
> > 1. Add some patch in run_test.sh. If the master node is not assigned, the script is skipped
> > 2. Add a check at the beginning of test script. For example, we may check the kubelet service. Skip the case if kubelet service is absent.
> 
> Thanks for pointing this out, Bing. I have not tried running pytests with `run_tests.sh` `-t` option before, I have only used an individual DUT. I tried adding a patch to `run_tests.sh` by adding `k8s` to `SKIP_FOLDERS` string and removing `k8s` from `SKIP_FOLDERS` when master node is assigned. Would that work?
> 
> Kubelet service is up when the DUT is connected to a master. It is possible that the kubelet service may be down even when a master has been assigned- unless we enforce that the DUT must start as joined to the master before running k8s pytests.

Look good to me. But we need keep in mind that the ```run_test.sh``` script needed to be updated if we relocate the k8s test scripts.

latestReviews.body:
LGTM now. The only concern is that the k8s cluster cannot be shared by multiple test setups at the same time. 

One possible way is to define a dedicated k8s cluster for each test setup. This would require more resources on test server.

Anyway, more PRs are required to address this k8s cluster conflicting issue.

reviews.body:
The k8s masters can be shared by multiple test setups, right?
Since the tests need to start/stop api server on the masters, it is not possible to for multiple test setups to use the same set of k8s masters at the same time. There would be conflicts. How to resolve this?

LGTM now. The only concern is that the k8s cluster cannot be shared by multiple test setups at the same time. 

One possible way is to define a dedicated k8s cluster for each test setup. This would require more resources on test server.

Anyway, more PRs are required to address this k8s cluster conflicting issue.

All CLA requirements met.

> This test checked router MAC address in config_db after image upgrade and minigraph loading. Would it be easier to add a router MAC check in the upgrading tests than creating a new test?

This test was written to verify some specific flow. There was a bug, when sometimes after sonic upgrade there wasn't MAC address  on interfaces. Firstly was developed YML script to reproduce this issue (cyclic upgrade), then this script was modified and commited to sonic-mgmt repository.  And now I manage to rewrite this test to pytest
So I think that it a good idea do not throw away this test, because it helps to validate this  specific flow (cyclic sonic upgrade)
@ayurkiv-nvda You made a point of `cylic sonic upgrade`. Can you please address my other comments?

@wangxin  I fixed all your comments. Can you please approve and merge if there are no more remarks?
Thank you!
